stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on implementing and animating several NPCs for the Wild West level. He programmed the AI and animations for a Dry Bones enemy, designed a shootout minigame with a new 'Cow Boshy' character, and did technical prep work on a piano player NPC. Throughout the stream, he discussed his game design philosophies, technical optimizations, and frustrations with community-standard development tools.

development_findings.summary: Kaze justifies hacking Mario 64 over games like Mario Kart 64 because he believes its unique movement physics make it special and irreplaceable, whereas superior alternatives exist for Mario Kart.
development_findings.quote: Mario 64, there's something very unique about it and that is the physics, the movement that no other game coming after it can replicate. So Mario 64 is still kind of special in that sense. Mario Kart 64, I just don't see it.

development_findings.summary: A key technique Kaze uses to make NPC movement look natural is to dynamically scale the playback speed of their animations to match their movement velocity in the game world.
development_findings.quote: I was actually gonna scale this animation speeds with his walking speeds because I feel like that makes sense. Yeah, I usually scale animations with the walking speed, it is the easiest thing to make good-looking I think.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is aggressive about optimizing assets to save memory, demonstrated when he immediately cut the texture maps for a new NPC model into halves and quarters to reduce their footprint.
development_findings.quote: The reason I want small textures is because it saves a lot of memory.

development_findings.summary: When designing the Cow Boshy shootout minigame, Kaze deliberately included an accessibility feature where the challenge decreases with each loss to ensure all players can eventually succeed, regardless of their natural reaction time.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna make it so that every time you lose the game gets a little bit easier... reaction time is one of those fixed things where some people are gonna be unable to do this on the first try or ever, actually.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is highly confident in his project's technical performance, claiming his use of caching is more advanced than any other commercial or fan-made N64 game.
development_findings.quote: I don't think there has been a game on the N64 that uses cash as well as this one.

development_findings.summary: Kaze claims his version of the decompilation project runs significantly faster than the main Heka-micro (Hexam64) branch because he has implemented optimizations that the other team has not back-ported, suggesting a divergence in development priorities.
development_findings.quote: Hexam64's frame rate is way lower than this, it must be like at least 30% lower... they don't copy all the optimizations... they don't want to port it back because it would be a lot of work.

development_findings.summary: Kaze believes the justification for Donkey Kong 64 requiring the Expansion Pak for vertex lighting is 'bullshit' and likely a result of extremely inefficient programming rather than a genuine technical necessity.
development_findings.quote: There's a chance that they did the lighting by duplicating every single model in the game... if they did it in the stupidest way possible... then sure it makes sense that they need eight megabytes for it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is working on a collaboration level with a creator named Aeza for a separate project, but plans to 'double cash in' by also including the level in Return to Yoshi's Island.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the best games provide intrinsic motivation (fun for its own sake) rather than extrinsic motivation (doing tasks for a reward), citing Pok√©mon as feeling like a 'job' and Tears of the Kingdom as a prime example of intrinsic fun.
context_findings.quote: If you play a game like Tears of the Kingdom and you build a machine, it's a fucking waste of your time practically speaking, but it's fun. That's pure intrinsic motivation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses strong disdain for what he considers 'parasocial farming' by other streamers, specifically finding mundane personal conversations, like discussing meals, to be narcissistic and uninteresting.
context_findings.quote: Talking what you ate feels so incredibly narcissistic to me. It's like, who gives a shit? You think you're that special that anyone cares what you ate?

context_findings.summary: Kaze's primary motivation for his projects, including past ones like 'Lost Levels,' is experimentation and learning. He creates things he wants to see and to improve his own skills, even if the concepts aren't universally popular.
context_findings.quote: I'm gonna make 32 linear levels to make sure that I'm good at making linear levels, right? I'm gonna learn as much from this as possible. That's always my mindset.

context_findings.summary: Kaze briefly mused on a dystopian future where corporations could copyright human DNA modifications, leading to a scenario where basic life functions could be subject to copyright infringement.
context_findings.quote: It's crazy we didn't beat cancer yet considering whales basically never get cancer and there's so many more cells... and then someone would make a DNA modification that would allow us to beat cancer and then they copyright the DNA modification and you're not allowed to breathe anymore without the permission of Walt Disney.

context_findings.summary: Kaze gets audibly frustrated and aggressive when dealing with chat questions he perceives as stupid but earnestly asked, stating he can't be mean and 'feel righteous about it,' which makes the situation upsetting for him.

biobak.summary: Biobak was present in the chat and Kaze shared a link to a secret collaboration level with him via DMs to get his opinion, indicating Biobak serves as a trusted confidant for work-in-progress.
Kaze asked Biobak for a hotkey related to unpacking resources in their 3D software, but Biobak did not know it.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the animations for the Dry Bones enemy, including a standard walk and a 'zombie walk,' which Kaze praised and implemented.
zeina.quote: Zayna, the Dry Bones look really, really good in-game. You will love them.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the model and a full set of animations for the 'Cow Boshy' character, which is the centerpiece of a shootout minigame.
Zeina provided the model for a piano-playing NPC. Kaze had to perform technical cleanup on the asset, including optimizing textures, fixing the UV map, and weighting bones on the rig.
zeina.quote: Zayna shy voice not very descriptive

zeina.summary: Kaze and Zeina's personal and professional lives are intertwined; he casually asked her for his credit card information on stream to make a work-related purchase.
zeina.quote: You still have my credit card, right, Zeina? I'll need that to buy the thing.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Dry Bones
key_stories.summary: Kaze took animations for a Dry Bones enemy created by Zeina and brought it to life in-game. He meticulously programmed its AI, sounds, and reactions, taking specific inspiration from the enemy's behavior in the New Super Mario Bros. series to create a polished final product.
key_stories.challenge: A new Dry Bones enemy needed to be implemented, requiring animations, AI behavior, and sound design to feel authentic and polished.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviewed animations from Zeina, selecting a 'zombie walk' for character. He coded the chase AI with line-of-sight, scaled animation speed to movement, and debugged acceleration. He meticulously recreated the 'crumble' animation from New Super Mario Bros. and solved a sound priority bug to add Koopa footstep sounds.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a polished Dry Bones enemy with chase logic, sound effects, and a crumbling behavior that closely mimics its appearance in official Nintendo games, making him proud of his specific skill in recreating it.
key_stories.key_quote: Man, I'm good at such a specific thing. I'm probably the world champion of matching the big dry bones behavior in New Super Mario Bros. games.

key_stories.title: Designing the Cow Boshy Duel
key_stories.summary: Using a new 'Cow Boshy' model from Zeina, Kaze designed a complete shootout minigame from scratch on stream. He focused on establishing the character's edgy personality through dialogue and ensuring the gameplay was accessible to all players by making it easier after each loss.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to design and implement a shootout minigame with the new 'Cow Boshy' character created by Zeina.
key_stories.process: Kaze defined Cow Boshy's 'arrogant, angsty, edgy' personality. He then outlined the duel's mechanics, including a countdown with a random delay and a dynamic difficulty system. He wrote extensive dialogue, set up the camera for a cinematic feel, and began debugging the initial interaction trigger.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze fully designed the minigame's flow, dialogue, and accessibility features. He began implementation, setting up the character, writing cowboy-themed dialogue, and programming the introductory cutscene and camera work for the duel.
key_stories.key_quote: We're gonna make it so that every time you lose the game gets a little bit easier, just to make sure everyone can beat it, because reaction time is one of those fixed things.

key_stories.title: The Emulator and Hardware Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed his frustrations with the standard tools used by the N64 modding community. He explained why the popular Parallel emulator doesn't work for him and why he's abandoning Everdrive flash carts, ultimately deciding to purchase a community-made 'Summer Cart' for more reliable hardware testing.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's choice of development tools, specifically his emulator and N64 cartridge, was discussed, revealing issues with standard community recommendations.
key_stories.process: Kaze defended his use of the older Project64 1.6 for its convenience. He recounted his negative experiences with the Parallel emulator, which doesn't work on his PC despite direct help from its developer, and his annoyance with users who incessantly recommend it. He also dismissed his Everdrive X5 as 'bugged,' leading him to research and decide on the Summer Cart.
key_stories.outcome: After explaining his frustrations with the popular Parallel emulator and the unreliable Everdrive flash cart, Kaze decided on stream to purchase a 'Summer Cart,' a community-made alternative that he believes is cheaper, more functional, and more reliable for his development needs.
key_stories.key_quote: Lots of people swear on Parallel Launcher but the people are really fucking obnoxious... even if you tell them it literally doesn't fucking work on my computer they will tell you just go Parallel Launcher.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he is working on a 'collab level' with a creator named Aeza for a project called 'sec'. He also plans to use this level in 'Return to Yoshi's Island' to 'double cash in'.
questions: What is the 'sec' project and what is the nature of your collaboration with Aeza?
How does collaborating with other creators influence your own design process?
You mentioned 'double cashing in.' Can you elaborate on the business or monetization strategy behind your projects?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that the 'new F3DEX' is 'still too slow' on his end and that he will 'have to debug it another day with Sauraen'.
questions: What is the 'new F3DEX' and what performance benefits is it supposed to provide?
What is the technical nature of the slowdown you're experiencing?
How critical is fixing this for the project's overall performance goals?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that his project's framerate is significantly higher than Hexam64's because they haven't ported his optimizations, and he wouldn't want to work off their repo due to 'random changes.'
questions: Could you describe some of the key optimizations you've made that differ from the main Hexam64 repository?
Why do you think there's a divergence in development philosophy between your project and the main branch?
What are some of the 'random changes' in Hexam64 that you disagree with?

open_questions.topic: Kaze and Zeina's Asset Creation Workflow
open_questions.context: Kaze received models from Zeina and performed technical cleanup, such as fixing rigs and optimizing textures. He noted one rig issue was a common first-timer mistake.
questions: Can you describe your typical collaborative workflow with Zeina for creating a new character, from concept to in-game?
Is it standard for you to handle the final technical polish on assets, or is that a shared responsibility?
How has your professional collaboration evolved over time, especially as you both gain more experience?

open_questions.topic: Importance of Real Hardware and the Summer Cart
open_questions.context: After expressing frustration with the Everdrive X5 flash cart, Kaze decided to purchase a 'Summer Cart,' a custom hardware solution made by a community member.
questions: How important is testing on original N64 hardware to your development process?
What specific problems with emulators or other flash carts does the Summer Cart solve for you?
Does developing for real hardware impose limitations that you wouldn't have if you were only targeting emulators?
